episodes.title: Inside Jared Leto's "Cult": The Thirty Seconds to Mars Echelon
episodes.description:
He calls his fans a cult – and they wear it like a badge. Jared Leto, an Oscar-winning actor turned rock frontman, has built a fanbase so devout that it’s drawn comparisons to a religious cult. Clad in white robes on a private island, Leto addressed hundreds of followers in scenes eerily reminiscent of a spiritual retreat, even captioning one 2019 photo, “Yes, this is a cult.”

 In truth, these fans call themselves The Echelon, a tight-knit community around Leto’s band Thirty Seconds to Mars – a group the band itself once cheerfully described as “a cult” from early on

. How did a Hollywood star’s rock band inspire such fervent, cult-like devotion? This video goes behind the sensational headlines and viral images to find out.

Today, we delve into Thirty Seconds to Mars’ unusual journey from its formation in 1998 to the creation of an obsessive fan community. We explore the band’s early days and the rise of the Echelon fan culture, including the symbolic slogans and cult imagery (like the now-infamous “Yes, this is a cult” tagline) that Leto and his brother Shannon wove into their music and merch

You’ll see how these immersive events and rituals fueled the “cult” reputation, and hear how media coverage amplified the mystique (with headlines dubbing Leto a real-life cult leader). We also compare the Echelon’s structure and us-vs-them mentality with bona fide cults, asking where the line blurs between an ardent fan community and a cult of personality. Finally, the film reveals Jared Leto’s response to the cult allegations – including his insistence that it’s all an inside joke
 – and invites you to decide just how far is too far when fandom turns fanatic. Join us as we uncover the truth behind the hype, exposing the fine line between passionate fandom and the cult of Mars.

episodes.title: Heaven’s Gate: The Rise, Beliefs, and Tragic End of a UFO Cult
episodes.description:
In this in-depth documentary, we explore the story of Heaven’s Gate, the infamous cult that captured the world’s attention in 1997 when 39 of its members were found dead in a mass suicide in Rancho Santa Fe, California. Led by Marshall Applewhite and Bonnie Nettles—known as “Do” and “Ti”—Heaven’s Gate was founded on a unique blend of Christian eschatology, New Age mysticism, and science fiction. Applewhite and Nettles preached that they were divine guides sent to help their followers ascend to the “Next Level,” an extraterrestrial realm beyond Earth. 

Join us as we uncover how the group’s strict lifestyle, rules, and evolving doctrines drew in followers seeking enlightenment and belonging. We’ll dive into the journey from the initial recruitment tours of the 1970s to the events leading up to the group’s tragic “final exit” in 1997, when they believed a spacecraft behind the Hale-Bopp comet would transport their souls to salvation.

Discover what led so many intelligent individuals to abandon their former lives, cut ties with family, and surrender to the teachings of Applewhite. Through their farewell videos and the symbolic rituals of their last moments, we’ll explore the powerful influence of belief and the dangers of charismatic leadership.
